shortdesc.ph: Sets the zoom factor of the camera.

section.p: Some iOS devices have rear cameras composed of multiple lenses, such as dual cameras (wide-angle and ultra-wide-angle) or triple cameras (wide-angle, ultra-wide-angle, and telephoto). For such composite lenses with ultra-wide-angle capabilities, you can call and set cameraFocalLengthType to CameraFocalLengthDefault (0) (standard lens), then call this method to set the camera zoom factor to a value less than 1.0 to achieve an ultra-wide-angle shooting effect.

Some iOS devices use a composite rear camera consisting of multiple lenses, such as dual cameras (wide-angle and ultra-wide-angle) or triple cameras (wide-angle, ultra-wide-angle, and telephoto). For such composite lenses with ultra-wide-angle capability, you can call to set cameraFocalLengthType to cameraFocalLengthDefault (0) (standard lens), and then call this method to set the camera zoom factor to a value less than 1.0 to achieve an ultra-wide-angle shooting effect.

Some iOS devices have composite rear cameras consisting of multiple lenses, such as dual-camera (wide and ultra-wide) or triple-camera (wide, ultra-wide, and telephoto). For such composite lenses with ultra-wide capability, you can call to set cameraFocalLengthType to CAMERA_FOCAL_LENGTH_DEFAULT (0) (standard lens), and then call this method to set the zoom factor to a value less than 1.0 to achieve an ultra-wide-angle effect.

ul.li: You must call this method after . The setting takes effect after the camera is successfully turned on, that is, when the SDK triggers the callback and returns the local video state as LocalVideoStreamStateCapturing (1).
This method is applicable only to Android and iOS.

You must call this method after . The setting takes effect after the camera is successfully started, that is, when the SDK triggers the callback and returns the local video state as localVideoStreamStateCapturing (1).
This method is applicable to Android and iOS only.

You must call this method after . The setting takes effect after the camera is successfully started, that is, after the SDK triggers the callback and returns the local video state as LOCAL_VIDEO_STREAM_STATE_CAPTURING (1).

plentry.pd: The zoom factor of the camera. For devices that do not support ultra-wide-angle, the range is from 1.0 to the maximum zoom factor; for devices that support ultra-wide-angle, the range is from 0.5 to the maximum zoom factor. You can use to get the maximum zoom factor supported by the device.

Camera zoom factor. For devices that do not support ultra-wide-angle, the value ranges from 1.0 to the maximum zoom factor; for devices that support ultra-wide-angle, the value ranges from 0.5 to the maximum zoom factor. You can call to get the maximum zoom factor supported by the device.

Camera zoom factor. For devices that do not support ultra-wide-angle, the range is from 1.0 to the maximum zoom factor. For devices that support ultra-wide-angle, the range is from 0.5 to the maximum zoom factor. You can call to get the maximum supported zoom factor.

section.title: Return Values

ul.li: If the method call succeeds: returns the set factor value.
If the method call fails: returns a value < 0.

section.p:
When the method call succeeds, there is no return value; when fails, the exception is thrown. You need to catch the exception and handle it accordingly. See [Error Codes](https://docs.agora.io/en/video-calling/troubleshooting/error-codes) for details and resolution suggestions.
Failure: return value < 0.

ul.li: On success: Returns the set factor value.
